nodes.bodyText: Can omit "property.isInterleaved() " condition here, since the previous condition would have caught it.
Leave a comment about what should happen if the property is interleaved lazily (that it's skipped and not persistent)?
I don't think I understand what happens if the number of parent key parts exceeds the number of child key parts. Is that even supposed to happen?

Let's check if I understand: the "and" conditions make sure the parent and child key for a single row match. And the "or" conditions match multiple rows' worth of keys?
I would take my confusion as an opportunity to factor out some logic into helper methods. For example, the while loop could go into a method named "singleRowKeyMatchCondition)". Better yet, those could go into a helper class that could be unit tested.
The goal of this would be to make it trivial for someone troubleshooting a production issue to look at the code and understand what it's doing.

I wonder if it makes sense to pass string builders around as the query gets constructed instead of returning strings that have to, in turn, be concatenated. For a high-volume system, all this string concatenation will add up.
Comment that when options are there the new strategy is n/a.
Can you make the for loop and the while loop separate private methods for readability?
Maybe isEagerInterleaved() to be consistent with isLazyInterleaved()?
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -113,4 +113,11 @@
 	 * @return {@code true} if the property is lazily-fetched. {@code false} otherwise.
 	 */
 	boolean isLazyInterleaved();
+
+	/**
+	 * Return whether this property is an eagerly-fetched interleaved property.
+	 * @return {@code true} if the property is eagerly-fetched. {@code false} otherwise.
+	 */
+	boolean isEagerlyInterleaved();

nodes.bodyText: Can you move it closer to isLazyInterleaved definition?
